conclusion: Consider the cylindrical light hole to be a cylinder of length (roof-thickness) d = 20√3 cm and inner diameter L = 40 cm.
In the vertical-longitudinal section the hole is a rectangle of height d and half-width L/2.
For the extreme ray that just grazes the cylindrical wall, the ray must start from the edge of the upper aperture (x = L/2) and arrive at the centre of the lower aperture (point A).
Calculate tan θ₀ = (L/2)/d = 1/√3, therefore θ₀ = arctan(1/√3) = 30°.
θ₀ is the largest incident angle (measured from the normal) that can reach A when the hole is filled with air.
Inside the brick the ray is still limited only by the geometry of the hole.
The largest possible angle inside the glass, θg,max, is the same 30°: tan θg,max = (L/2)/d = 1/√3 → θg,max = 30°.
At the top surface the ray passes from air (n₁ = 1) into glass (n₂ = √3).
Calculate n₁ sin θair,max = n₂ sin θg,max → sin θair,max = √3/2 = 0.866…
The ray emerging at the lower surface is also transmitted because n sin 30° = √3/2 < 1, so no total internal reflection occurs.
Embedding the glass brick enlarges the range of incident angles that can reach the central point at the bottom of the hole by 30°.
